However, the real difference comes when we both play R or B simultaneously. If we both play R, we get 45$, but if we both play B, we each earn 40$.

To make a profitable strategy, I should try to maximize the number of times my opponent chooses R and I choose B. Since I have no information about my opponent's strategy, I will assume they might have similar reasoning as me, meaning they would also want to maximize their payout by choosing B when I pick R and vice versa.

Now, let's look at the average payoff over 75 rounds:
- If I play B every time, my average payout will be (75 * 40) / 75 = 40$ per round
- If I play R every time, my average payout will be (35 * number of times opponent picks R) + (0 * number of times opponent picks B). Since the opponent also follows a strategy that maximizes their own profit, they will choose R less than 50% of the time. So, for a realistic estimate, let's assume my average payout when playing R is below 40$.

Based on this analysis, I would choose B (B{) as my strategy to maximize my long-term profit in this game.
